job_title: Full Time Staff Member in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Student centered. Diverse. Faculty and staff go above and beyond to serve their students. Great location. Large access to internships and careers. Mission focused.
cons: While the student body is very diverse, there's not a lot of diversity among leadership positions.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros:
Great work environment!
Great team culture!
cons: Okay benefits, could be better to match the compensation.

pros: I love the students - they are the only reason I've stayed as long as I have. The school has a very diverse group of students which is fun and exciting to teach within and learn from.
cons:
Pay is low, but this is an industry-wide issue. The contract and part-time faculty are ignored and often talked down to as though we don't know what we are doing. They seem to be moving towards a for-profit model and moving most classes online, which are all 7-week courses . 

All syllabi are being modularized with teaching freedoms removed - making individual experience and expertise unimportant. They try to suggest that we still have academic freedom to add uniqueness to the lectures, but those are all dictated to you, and we are not allowed to change anything within the syllabus or how blackboard is set up. The value of bringing decades of practical industry experience to teaching is not there. The changes are significant and being incorporated quicker. Many full-time faculty have responded to these changes by leaving - most within the last 6 months. You need to be a part of the "in-group" that is moving the University to this for-profit model, or you are pushed out through extreme micromanaging, marginalization and/or demotions. 

I've seen some talented faculty be broken down and replaced by younger, less insightful, and experienced faculty who won't challenge anyone. It's demotivating and concerning. I'm not sure how much longer I will keep teaching here. When you teach part-time, you do so because you want to help students learn what they need to know in the workplace, and you have critical insights as to what is required and why. There is no other motivation - as pay certainly isn't. Why would anyone teach part-time or as a contractor if we weren't truly dedicated to teaching students what they need to know? So with your doctorate, you can make less than $15/hr? We'd all make more money working at fast-food restaurants would likely experience far less micromanagement and endure fewer condescending conversations.

review_title: Does not feel like a university
job_title: Assistant Professor in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Small campus with friendly faculty and staff.  Great location within St. Paul.  Classroom sizes are capped at 24.  The online programs are a plus for working adult students.  Diverse student population.  Inclusive of students of other religions even though it is a Lutheran university.
cons: Concordia saves money by employing mostly adjuncts at a low rate, canned materials created by a third party and lack of technology labs and technology in the classrooms. The buildings are outdated with weird classroom dimensions and heating and cooling problems.  The institution operates with a lean-and-mean corporate culture and little resembling a real university.  Pay is low for a 12-month contract.  Expect to work during summer.  Higher up selects who they want to promote.  Evaluation process leaves too much room for bias and abuse.  Department chair has too much power and their role are permanent.   They favor conformity over quality and creativity.  Little or no diversity in the faculty and staff.  High turn over rate.  Overly concern about things that matter little in teaching.

review_title: If you are immobile and really want to teach this can be a place for you.
pros: Flexible time,teaching can be fun, good colleagues. Benefits aren't bad but are getting worse. Lots of time off if you are not an administrator.
cons: Very paternalistic. Decisions are made without input. They don't always follow policies or procedures and violate Matthew 18 regularly. Don't cross anyone. they stab in the back with impunity.

review_title: While there are many great people who work at CSP, it is a complex organization to work for.
pros: Great employees (mostly), mission driven, unpretentious, interesting students, great women's volleyball, free parking, great location (midway between downtown Minneapolis and downtown St. Paul).
cons: Very conservative theologically, low pay/heavy work load, very tight financially, mysterious to poor HR and at least some (not all) of the faculty leadership.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Faculty and staff committed to proving quality education
cons: Adjunct pay is considerably lower than that which a graduate student would receive for teaching the same class.
